posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
I'd like to use a new term that applies to almost all FE games.

Puzzle Tactics game.

It's a "tactics" game where the emphasis is on "solving" a level by doing a very precise and rigid set of moves with very little room for improv.
To that end FE games tend to have side-objectives that emphasize rushing towards a part of the map where some unit is doing something on a "timer" so you have to immediately move a certain way with certain units to reach it. Also the weapon triangle makes it so very specific units can defeat other ones which are statically placed so you have to send a certain unit a certain way to accomplish that. Also the weapon triangle makes it so using a wrong unit can have them wiped out in even one attack, which reinforces the "correct" way of doing things and minimizes improv.

Games that would fit in this sub-genre are also Advanced Wars and (not retro) Into the Breach.

An example of a non-puzzle tactics game is Tactics Ogre, where you have more control over your party customization and loadout and the enemies can be defeated in a more fluid, back-and-forth way. Certain maps where you recruit special units are tailored mostly towards rushing them a specific way, but these are generally rare and special cases. In general you can flop around, lose some units, recover, and legitimately use "tactics" to win.
UFO and XCOM are also "true" tactics games.

My point is that the game forces you into a very narrow "problem-solving" approach both in map layout, units given and so on... certain units are specifically designated to defeat certain opponents and you almost always have to use them that way.

In "true" tactics games like XCOM or Tactics Ogre you are given a far more broad approach in dealing with situations tactically, rather than treating levels/battles as problems to solve a very specific way.

>>9646353
>why are there so many tactics ogre/fft clones but so little fire emblem clones?
I suspect it's for the same reason that there are so many Castlevania clones and so few Metroid clones. Namely, that the majority of people don't fully appreciate the subtle differences between the two and so anyone asking for Metroid-like games is pointed toward Castlevania-like games as if it's all the same. Similarly, anyone who asks for Fire Emblem-like games is simply pointed to FFT-like games instead.

I think it comes from one game just being more popular than the other so that's what gets copied most and then people who don't respect the nuanced differences between the two don't drive any demand for copies of the less popular one because they don't even see a need for it.

>>9656819
>Well that's a perspective I've never heard before and does make the idea of just skipping to FE3 a lot more appealing.
If you only want to touch any form of that game once, then yes skip to Book 1 of Mystery of the Emblem. I will say there is a magic to FE1 that no other FE games have that I feel warrants at least one playthrough, though the inventory system might be frustrating to deal with as it is admittedly clunky. But there's a magic to playing the games in order of release and seeing the evolution there. Otherwise you would have to play half of a SNES game, go back to play Fire Emblem Gaiden on the NES, then go back for the other half of the SNES game to play in order of "1, 2, 3" for the games.
The inventory system might of the original Shadow Dragon might be frustrating to deal with, though. Even when the game wasn't even a year old yet there was an interview with the series creator on Famitsu and he talked about how people complained about that inventory system. So in the SNES remake he listened to the criticism and he overhauled it to be more easy to use and far less clunky.

I've not played all that much FE but that doesn't match my experience with them at all. Maybe on those really hard difficulty modes all the new games have now, but not on normal or hard in the older games.

They tend to have so many more playable units than there are deployment slots people just use their favourites and send everyone else to the bench, so it's not as if you're forced to use specific characters much.

And sure, you could argue those characters aren't always that different statistically, but you don't need to use especially specific class compositions either. You probably want a few staff-users and cavaliers, but when it comes to things like knights or archers, some people love them while others can't be bothered with them, and both get by just fine. You can take very different teams into the same map and come out on top. Not to mention sometimes a unit dies and you have to adapt to that. Sure you can reset, but not resetting or only resetting for really painful losses are definitely supported playstyles as well.

Regarding Advance Wars as well, maybe you only meant single-player, but AW has a big multiplayer community as well which doesn't seem plausible were it really a puzzle game.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>9657201
>Game was wasted on N64.
Yes and no.

From the developer's perspective a visual novel was a low cost way to push software onto a new platform.

However, from the customer's perspective...An expensive cartridge that also required additional hardware was a hard sale. In 1996 people still hadn't accepted memory cards as a standard peripheral yet. As a consumer it simply made more sense to buy a cartridge JRPG with battery backup rather than whatever the fuck this was(a low spec PC game that required a separate memory card basically.)

>But the game came with a memory card!
Yeah but not for free. Did you mother fuckers forget having to pay as much or more for a memory card when it was an emerging technology? Eighty dollar video games except you can't save your progress because you also have to buy this separate piece of hardware for an additional fifty dollars and with tax you're now paying one hundred and forty dollars for this visual novel slideshow.

So basically a third of the price of a console just to play a watered down version of Princess Maker on emergent technology. Precisely why there wasn't a Wonder Project J3. Back then people couldn't justify paying so much for so little.

>>9662123
More than that, many characters also have unique equipment loadouts that keep them relevant even after their special abilities become weak. By the end of the game, many if not most of the characters no longer rely as much on their specials, as most of them are surpassed by Magic (which everyone can learn) and Fight or a variant thereof (such as Jump or X-Fight), but are kept unique by their equipment setups. So Setzer goes from being the Slots guy to the Fixed Dice + Offering guy, and Mog goes from being centered around his Dances into becoming a powerful Dragoon tank, for example, all thanks to their unique weapons. Only Terra and Celes are effectively clones here.

While it is a little known fact that a good half of the enemies in Dragon Warrior 2 hand out more exp/gold than their counterparts in Dragon Quest 2, what nobody knowns (and which isn't documented yet) is that the stats of all enemies were also rebalanced for the western version.

Every enemy in Dragon Warrior 2 is easier. Whether that is attack, def or agility, values, and I think in some cases even HP and probability to use this or that move (I'd have to check back to make sure of that). In most cases there are subtle changes to most values.

So when you see people who have played Dragon *Warrior* 2 and hear them cry about
>waaah this game is too hard! I mean the end game is hard how does that make sense??!! Look even the devs said it was too hard!
They have absolutely no right to use the dev stuff as an excuse because they were already playing a version in which the difficulty had been adressed to begin with.

Dilate.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9633787
While it is a technical possibility to get ambushed and OHKO'd from a death spell in the late game, it is very unlikely to happen when you reached the level gap. The higher your level, the less likely you will be to get ambushed, and the less likely death spells will be likely to hit.

>>9633749
>specially the sun one which is found on a specific tile on a southeastern shrine.

There is an NPC that tells you exactly where the shard is. That and you get the flute to help you locate the shards.That and the shrine is likely to be a place you visit when you use the warps.

As long as you pay attention and take notes when NPCs say things, you shouldn't have too much trouble.
Personally I love this stuff in the game, these adventure game mechanics are exactly what makes the game feel organic and alive, rather than having a game-y world with a tired "area is composed of one town, one dungeon, complete that and you're allowed to go the next area and repeat" routine.
In DQ2 towns work as hubs you come back to
in between several quests, and their inhabitants often provide clues that will be needed for things much later on; that and there is often a reason to come back to X or Y location later on. This makes the world feel alive and enhances the feel of adventure, something many other RPGs (DQ sequels included) fail at because they want to cater to the part of the audiance that just wanted to be hand holded through an adventure game.

The source is me checking the game code coupled with existing dissassembly and documentation to help (though I don't trust the dissassembly too much because external docs that come with it talk about things which aren't in the game at all, must be a romhack or something)

Example, Big Slug data in the Japanese version
08 00 03 01 04 0B 06 00 07 00 00 00 00 00

Big Slug data in the US version
08 00 03 02 03 09 06 00 07 00 00 00 00 00

So on top of the exp given being changed from 01 to 02 (already a known thing easily checked by playing or checking guides), the attack value was changed from 0B to 09, losing 2 points.

Pretty much every enemy has changes like that, some more substantial than that too.

I'll document it all one of these days, but it takes time; and I intend to check up on other things too like probability for enemies to use this or that spell or to drop items etc

>>9643352
>know more than the devs

The "we didn't have time to properly test and balance the game" excuse was from a Japanese interview, thus talking about the Japanese version. One should also take into account that they spent one month and a half (november/december 1986) doing nothing but debugging and balancing the game. That's a lot of time. The game was delayed for that purpose specifically.
The fact is, making RPGs hard and require grinding was a norm then, which as a whole gradually decreased with time (and the US version is from 1990, thus the adjustements)

>>9646454
>he doesn't memorize an approximate amount of HP each enemy has to be as efficient as possible in combat
First off, enemies in DQ have a range of HP, something with 100 HP isn't always going to have that amount when you encounter it, you could encounter two of the same enemy but one will die earlier because it had 92 HP while the other had 103, the same is true for the amount of gold that enemies drop. This makes it especially difficult to try and not trigger a 25% range.
Secondly, I'm skeptical of the 25% HP thing even being true because from what I could find, one source says its 1/3 HP and another says its a remake addition and doesn't specify a threshold for "low" HP.
>Also you make it sound like one cast of Twhack/Sacrifice is going to wipe out your entire team every time
Did you not play DQ2 on NES? Sacrifice aka Kamikazee is a 100% guaranteed full party wipe, there is no chance of it failing, you just instantly lose. The same is true for when you have Cannock use it, although some enemies have the blessing of being immune to instant death.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
I just checked the code (again, US NES version) and whenever Gold Batboons attempts to do Sacrifice, it checks its remaining HP and compares it to value 1C, which equals 28 in decimal; and proceeds to fuck off if the value is higher.
28 being 25% of 112, the Gold Batboon's max HP value when it spawns (as stated HP may vary), so it's not really 25% of its health, but 25% of its max possible health.

One interesting thing I'm not sure I fully understand however is that if you have 2 Gold Batboons, it checks both enemies HP values. I *think* what happens is that Gold Batboon A may very well be the one to use Sacrifice if Gold Batboon B is the one with low HP; not that the player will know because he will be kill.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Gyakuten Saiban is pretty terrible sometimes, but when it's good it's as good as any VN.
Unfortunately, I think a lot of people have their opinion of it poisoned by the official translation, which is fairly awful.
The big issue with the series is that starting with 1 & 2 is more or less mandatory, and they're very inconsistent; a few great cases mixed in with some real stinkers. 1-3 and 2-3 in particular are fucking atrocious.
But Gyakuten Saiban 3 is fantastic from start to finish; as far as all-ages VNs go I'd be pressed to name one that's better. It's so good it's worth sitting through the worst of the first two VNs to be able to experience it with the full context.
The strength and weakness of the series is the gameplay; it allows you to get stuck in ways you can't in most modern VNs, but if you can resist the temptation to look up the answers and manage to solve the cases yourself it makes you feel like a genius. Seeing all the characters you've grown to know and care about smile and hug and cry in the lobby after it's all over and you (You! The player!) managed to save everyone never fails to make me all fuzzy-eyed.

Fun fact about the "Past" tracks is that they were sound chip sequences instead of CD audio like the other tracks. This was in order to have enough disc space for the rest of the tracks. This made them sound nostalgic and less modern in comparison to the other songs which worked in its favor. They were kept the same in the American release because it would've been too time consuming to redo them and Nilsen only had a few months to work with.

I think it was a good idea. It makes the gameplay more focused and it's great for the atmosphere. But I can understand the ones saying the game was too expensive for how little game you got. But I think it makes up for it in quality over quantity.

The lack of enemies apart from the bosses made the emptiness feel more peaceful too, which was a nice change of pace from the bosses, but also increased the feeling that maybe the colossi weren't so malevolent.

And all the empty space made it feel like you actually were an explorer. If Columbus had stopped at islands with towns littered across the Atlantic every day on his way to America he wouldn't be exploring, he'd just be globetrotting. Whether that kind of exploration is fun or has any place in a game can be debated though, it's definitely not for everyone.

To answer your question it is a CTGP machine (custom mario kart tracks. Really cool) and an emulation/ gamecube backup player.

When I was a poorfag between the ages of llike 17-21 the wii was my go to.
I had about half of my kino gc collection (my stupid ass fell for the trade in scam. Sold F-zero and Mario Party 4 for Reach and Black Ops in 2011 lol, still had most of my titles.)


Ended buying an external hardrive, and on would bring my laptop to the cafe of giant eage and enjoy a pumpkin roast while deciding on which gamecube game to download and what anime titles to pirate after work. (My parents were poor and skeptical of the internet, and I worked full time as a personal trainer.)

Life sucked, but it was also /comfy/ in a way. I remember the midwest autumn evenings that I spent with Fire emblem 9, 10 and the GBA titles, CTGP, Harvest Moon Wonderful life, and more

>>9655947
>when 480p is enabled
What are you even babbling about kid. Modern display means a HD screen no one is connecting a WiiU to a crt like a complete retard. Even the Wii had synch problems with some 240p screens and you had to set it to 480i to even use the feature in virtual console titles. Nintendo removed the option for 240p if you set your system to 480p in a firmware update a few months after the Wii dropped. Most people that think they use 240p on a Wii don't even know this. Main reason the WiiU doesn't support 240p is precisely because of the same sync issue the Wii had so nintendo removed the feature.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
The original PS had a metric shitload of games, and in spite of growing up with it, I never played THAT many games for it (had maybe 15 PS titles). Recently I've been revisiting the console and there have been a lot of fun lesser known games I've been playing.

Lucifer Ring is a sword and sorcery type 3D beat em up, a little basic and by the numbers, but some of the bosses are awesome and beat em ups in this old world setting aren't too common.

Brigandine is a very flavourful strategy game with a fantastic art direction and sense of style. I guess with games like Final Fantasy Tactics on the system, Brigandine was bound to be overlooked, but it really is great.

Also been playing Ape Escape. That's not really a niche title, but I've never played it before. It is very impressively polished and well thought out, just in general. I'm looking forward to checking out the other games in the series.

If you have any recommendations, let me know. Otherwise, just post about the PS below. PS2 is cool too.

The major difference is that it runs on a different engine. It uses the Baldur's Gate 2 engine. posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9658012
>I definitely couldn't beat Diablos as soon as he's available

You can beat him at pretty much any level since his primary attack is a gravity spell. It'll drain your hit points quickly but since its damage is percentage-based it shaves off less HP every time and can't actually kill you. You'll spend the fight with alarmingly low HP but that just means you can use limit breaks on every turn which actually just makes it much easier.

He *can* physically attack and kill weakened party members but he doesn't do it often and it only ends the game if he hits the MC. If you saved the game like they told you to before using it the worst case is you reload and beat him the next time. I always beat him as soon as I get the lamp and I'm always at extremely low levels. It's a fight designed to let you win because, again, his main attack cannot kill you and you will get to use limit breaks as much as you want.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9656513
I respect this point of view, but I don't draw my line in the sand that far. If a the censorship is minor enough I'll just shrug it off.
I think the most minor case of censorship in a game I'm aware of is the Japanese version of Gyakuten Saiban. There's a bit character in one of the games who is never seen on screen named 看護婦, which means "nurse". In the DS remakes her name was changed to 看護師, which is a slightly more polite word for nurse.
I just don't feel it's worth playing the GBA version over the DS version for that one word difference.

Another example is Masoukishin, one of the early Super Robot Taisen games. My understanding is that in the DS and PSP remakes four lines of dialogue that implied that a character was a former Islamic terrorist were changed.
By playing the original over the remakes, in exchange for those four lines of dialogue, you are giving up:
>The ability to play the game on a portable system
>The ability to make a temporary save whenever you want
>96 save files
>Voices
>Very pretty art, one of the best looking games both on DS and PSP
I mean, at some point, I'm willing to look up what lines were changed and replace them with the original in my head.
I definitely wouldn't want to pay money for a game that was censored, I don't support that. But Winky Soft went out of business seven years ago so at least for that game it's a moot point.

Yes. It has to do with pixel clock. Like most time keeping that's based on UTC. Tokyo is to the east, UTC+9, so pixels are shifted 9 to the right. NY is to the west, UTC-5, so pixels are shifted 5 to the left. Only in glorious bongistan PALland do you get pixels in the correct position. True story.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9653016
It's not hard to make a Mame machine. But it's time consuming and the experience isn't the same as it was back in the 90s.

Arcade cabs usually had 1 game (unless it was a Neo Geo). And it played instantly when you dropped a quarter it in. No wait times or scrolling through tons of menus.

With Mame, people put thousands of games on their MAME machines. You walk up to a Mame machine and you can spend 10 minutes just scrolling through menus. Annoying and It really kills the vibe.

Plus you need to download roms, setup mame, fiddle with settings (which can take hours or days), test everything, tweak the controls to your likeing, and install a front-end (the pretty menu that you scroll through when choosing a game).

And worst of all, everytime Mame updates you need to re-download all your Roms again because the roms aren't compatible with the new version. I don't know why they haven't figured out a better way. If there's an error, then you deal with a lot Mame elitists who insult you and claim your an idiot. Even though Mame looks like it's still stuck in the era Windows 98. They havent updated their UI in decades.

When I want to play an arcade game, I don't want to use a computer. I want to instantly jump in the action. I don't want to deal with menus, error messages, or any other stuff that crops up.

I don't hate Mame and applaud the Mame team for preserving games. But I prefer original hardware when possible. It just feels better and less headache with setup.

Plus there are so many companies making hundreds of thousands if not millions by selling expensive custom arcade cabinets. Usually anywhere form $10K to 25K in price.

>>9653426
I've spoken with many old school arcade operators. I can offer some of their thoughts.

Some arcade machines kept track of how much they earned in the hidden operator test settings. Data would display on how much money/quarters that players put inside the machine on each difficulty. You could track the data.

If you made the difficulty too high, then casual players would give up and stop playing because it was too hard.

If you made it too easy, then the game wouldn't be seen as a challenge and your casual players would easily beat the on less quarters. Which means you earn less money.

The idea was to find the perfect middle ground. You could adjust default CPU difficulty on a scale from level 1 to level 10 in many games.

If your arcade was in an area with mostly casual players and children, then you kept the difficulty on moderate. You go easy on the kids to lure more quarters out of them. Give them just enough hope and they will give you more quarters.

For an arcade that had a lot of "pro players", operators kept the difficulty on high because they would be more of a challenge to pro players.

For some games like Fighting games, you could even adjust the default damage level.

For example, in the Philippines the the damage level was actually kept on 50% instead of the normal 100%. Kids didn't have a lot of money, so arcade owners would lower the damage so the players that visited often would be able to "feel" like they got their money's worth. Matches would be extra long due to lower damage. But this kept visitors coming to arcades. This happened in many countries in Asia, South America, and the Pacific Islands where kids had less money.

In America and Europe the damage was set to 100%

This led to an interesting scenario in "Marvel VS Capcom 2" when they were trying to host worldwide tournaments. Players argued on what should be the default damage level. Players spend their whole careers being used to a specific damage level.

>This led to an interesting scenario in "Marvel VS Capcom 2" when they were trying to host worldwide tournaments. Players argued on what should be the default damage level. Players spend their whole careers being used to a specific damage level.

Part 2 - Continued

There was some arguments and debates on what should be the default damage level for worldwide Marvel VS Capcom tournaments.

As an Asian/Filipino/South American player, if you spent hundreds of hours (or even a few thousand hours) learning to play your team on a lower damage setting then your whole play style revolves around that damage levels. You know how EXACTLY much damage your character can take but still survive. Or How to recover, counter, etc. It will be very difficult to adjust to higher damage.

For players in America and Europe, you've trained your muscle memory to be able to execute the combos you need to exactly kill the enemy team with damage level set to 100%. If the damage level is set to 50%, then suddenly your combos that would kill the enemy team will still leave them alive.

So there were debates and arguments between players about it. I think the American Players and European players won out because... Well they are richer and put more money into hosting the tournaments. So they decided the rules.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9658824
>>9658752
>I know this question is contentious and has no real answer, but how do you feel about the notion of completing a 1cc of an arcade game in a real arcade with the knowledge that said machine may actually be running on easy mode? Do you think it still counts?

First of all it must be real hardware. Emulation does not (and will never) count.

There is a reason that official record holder websites like Twin Galaxies and other websites exist. And the rule is that it must be on original hardware. It's to hold everyone to same rules and same standards.

Games like Donkey Kong require a 4 way joystick (original manufacturer design). And Using other joysticks with more available directions actually give an unfair advantage in game. There are active lawsuits right now in the real world about records being false because of using the wrong joystick.

PC computers are not universal. Everyone has different setups. Emulation can be used to cheat and there have been numerous cases of people cheating. Like with DDR and Guitar Hero record holders who've been caught faking their records. They record themselves with the gameplay speed reduced to around 90% or 80% (because they can't do it at 100% speed), then use a video editing program to speed it back up to 100%.

Or people trying to claim "Shoot Em up" or 'Run and Gun' game records, but use autofire. For example games like Metal Slug (even though it was never available in the arcades).

There are two rules when it comes to claiming records and achievements.

1. It must be on the same unmodified arcade hardware. Emulation is not accepted.

2. It must be on the same settings.

>easy mode
Are you trying to beat the game on easy mode? Then OK.

But if you want a higher difficulty, then politely talk to arcade technician/manager/owner to check the machine and change the settings. People politely ask all the time. It's not a huge deal. They might might even support what you are doing.

>>9653101
I think the only way I can see your position is if you're considering "finish" to be distinct from "clear" or "beat". If that's not what it is then I don't understand your issue.
Many (not all) video games possess an end state. Score attack games have an end state; it's when the player has erred enough times. Competitive games have an end state; when one player wins or neither player is no longer eligible to win. Games focused on following a narrative have an end state; it's the conclusion of the story.
Generally games following a narrative place their credits after the conclusion of the story. This is a convention to notify the player they have finished the story and most likely the game itself. Exceptions exist but are not the common expectation.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Good game, and very underrated.
This is basically the PS1's Ocarina of Time - although it has more in common with Majora's Mask - and it released before both.
Cannot believe it wasn't on my radar. Maybe because it never released in PAL regions? Or perhaps because it's labelled as an action-rpg?
It's really an action-adventure game that just happens to have a leveling system you can safely ignore.
Health / BP is increased through exploration, and you unlock new abilities as the game progresses to be used in each dungeon / boss.
Add in a bunch of other systems: the copy-mechanic, day/night cycle, npc cycles, tiredness meter... the action-figure collection was neat. Wish it was used in the main game.
It has its flaws. Platforming and combat aren't great (sword too short, movement speed slightly too slow and sometimes slippery). Steamwood mini-game x2. And of course, the well.
But still - I always looked forward to playing it, and never felt compelled to check how much longer was left.

Fuck. What to play next... Is Threads of Fate worth checking out? Any cool systems? If not, I'll try Trap Gunner.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>9659884
That's a tough one. I really like the Sonic Adventure ones. It's a basic concept of having new aesthetics in the game world for events, but it adds a lot of excitement to its world. Another one that's pretty crazy are the Shenmue VMU "Passport Goodies." Each file was a unique sprite animation to play on your VMU. They made one for every single character model in the game (not just the human NPCs but all of the differeny birds and cats and such too). In total, there were 339 of these VMU animation files for the game, although 132 of them still remain lost, sadly. It wasn't easy to get these back in the day. Not counting the default 4 that came with Shenmue's VMU animation player, you had to receive a winning can from a market in-game and then connect to the online servers of the Passport disc to exchange one winning can for one animation of your choice. I'm surprised we have over 200 of these archived to be honest.

>>9660572
A good chunk of the Passport disc is offline, but is blocked off by a dial-up check. You can change two bytes to disable the dial-up check. Sadly, some of the information pages did need an internet connection, but amazingly one of the Japanese guidebooks cataloged every single one. Some fans translated them and used them in an app they made called "Suka Pass" that acts as the successor to Passport. Every single NPC has their own backstory and it's really cool.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9653010
Anything you want to have shortcuts to on the system menu should run from the memory card, I think. In my experience trying to start apps from a system menu shortcut can make the system lock up if the HDD has to spin up first.

If you're concerned about memory card space you shouldn't really be using your FMCB card for game saves anyway. Best to just load up all your homebrew onto one card and use another one for saves (or a virtual card on the HDD)

Easy way to test this is to put in PS1 games or CDs and see if they work. If they work then the DVD laser is dead/dying and you need to replace it. Replacing the laser on the slim model is easy but you need a soldering iron to remove the anti static solder point. See pic related.

>>9661043
I'd say that it's even better aswell. Spider-Man: Mysterio's Menace (2001/GBA) is a weird one, because it's sort of a sequel to both Spider-Man duologies from that time, on PS1 and GBC, and it worked well for both. As for how it plays, it's 2D, just like both GBC installments, and takes elements from both, like the upgrades and overall open design from Vicarious Visions' 1st effort, while also having actual levels like Torus' sequel. While it isn't 3D, it clearly attempts to follow up on both PS1 installments, with its sprites and GUI/HUD clearly taken straight from it or at least inspired by it. All is good here, graphics are nice and make it look like a PS1 installment, OST is both catchy and atmospheric, level design is perfect for exploration while staying simple if you just want to go from start to finish. I'd say that you could struggle with some of its bosses, but unless you're playing on Super Hero difficulty then it shouldn't take too long for a strategy to become clear for you. I definitely recommend it, as it's everything a 2D Spider-Man video game should be.

You know what is weird about this game? The US disk is one of the few games, along with NiGHTS, that is region free. For some reason, starting the game normally on a Japanese saturn will not cause this bug. If you insert a Pseudo Saturn into the Japanese console and launch the legitimate game that way, the glitch will come back. Starting the game normally on a US system causes the glitch.

The US version of Croc may very well be the only game that just doesn't work at all with Pseudo Saturn. I'm not an expert so somebody with more knowledge should correct me, but it has something to do with one of the system components being disabled in the game, and somehow, opening the game from the menu re-enables it. But other region Saturns must be different, because it's enabled from the beginning with a Japanese console and then disables when you load it through cartridge.

>>9645658
For gen 1 either the Super GameBoy on the SNES or Pokemon Stadium with the Transfer PAK on the N64.

For gen 2, GBC, SGB or Transfer Pak. Gold and Silver look great on the SGB, but if you want to play Crystal on the TV, you'll need the Transfer Pak.

PS. The SGB has a hidden fast speed setting, similar to Doduo/Dodrio mode in Stadium, but you need a special SNES controller to access it.

PPS. Also worth noting, if you have a GBC, is that there's two interesting hacks for gen 1 games: one adds full color to them, the second adds better sprites from gen 2. You'll have a fully colored gen 1 experience that feels fresh, but you cannot use them hacks with a mono GB, SGB or Game Boy Tower in Stadium sadly.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Short version:
>play Pokémon red or blue on an OG Game Boy or a Super Game Boy.

Full Pocket Monsters experience: a /vr/ guide
>know absolutely nothing about the franchise and first engage with it through newspapers articles about a cartoon show that caused epileptic attacks on children in Japan
>read video game magazine articles that talk about a social phenomenon in Japan, called "Pocket Monsters", see some small screenshots and design imagen and think it looks weird and foreign but cool
>Call up various local game stores and ask them if they sell this japanese Pocket Monsters Game, only for them to have no idea
>forget about it for a while and one day you casually watch the first episode of "Pokémon" on cable TV and then you keep watching all the first season, meanwhile:
>Get Red or Blue and play on a Game Boy, or a Super Game Boy. Better alternative: GB tower on Pokémon Stadium, and using Oak's Lab for item and pkmn management, much better than the menues on the GB games. But, for a first playthrough it's not mandatory.
>Once you beat the game and catch Mewtwo, watch Mewtwo Strikes Back kino
>Read the "electric tale of Pikachu" manga
>Get a friend or a way to get the Pokémon from the other version that you're missing. Play Stadium's gym leader castle to get starters, fossils, eeveees and hitmons.
>Also try to beat the different cups in the main Stadium game as a post-game challenge. Start training low level Pokémon and buff them/give TMs and customize them.
>Buy at least a pack of the TCG, even if you don't care playing it, it's good art on them.
>play Pokémon Pinball and the Game Boy TCGs if you want somen extra gen 1 experience on GB
>play Snap and Smash 64
>Start reading rumours about pikablu
>Get hype for "Pokémon 2"
>Download a japanese ROM of Pokémon Gold and play a bit of it on a poorly coded emulator
>Play the actual Gold or Silver cart on a GB Color or go full pokemaster and play on Stadium 2 using the GB Tower, then play the Stadium cups.

O and if you're playing the Japanese ROMs (doubt it?) of Gold and Silver, you'll have a purple Jynx sprite instead of black, same way it's been for years everywhere else. And... I think that's it? One way or another, they're killing the whole transfer thingy eventually, since they're shutting down 3DS e-shop by the end of March this year. For now, while you still can, just download the whole Pokemon Bank / Transporter app suite. You won't be able to download and set it up after March. For the VC releases, just download the ROM injects matching the region of your Nintendo account, you don't need to actually buy the games. I repeat, you do not need to buy the games in order to transfer Pokemon, you need the apps tied to your account and that's it.

I'm not a big fan of the 3rd gen in general, because as is the case with the human body - it consists mostly of water. All of that said, the engine is sound (think fastest Pokemon games overall, both in terms of movement and responsiveness), the spritework good - it's the newer entries that are kinda "meh". FireRed and LeafGreen aren't half bad though. They're not ground breaking, but do fix some bugs, introduce postgame content (not nearly as much as Emerald, but still), quality of life improvements and the artwork matches. "Shit" is kinda pushing it anon, IMHO. Plus you need to consider that before the VC releases of gen 1 and 2 games, if you wanted to see your Pokemon in newer entries - you had to start all over again with 3rd gen games. Mighty annoying and kinda fucked up, but it was what it was. If not for the existence of FR and LG, a lot of Kanto and Johto Pokemon would be stuck in limbo for years to come.

posts.sub: Did any super nintendo games use dithering?
posts.com: If so, post examples! I'm trying to figure out how I want to display muh gaems.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9661118
Most video games from ~1987 - 2008 made conscious artistic decisions based on the limitations of the screens they would be played on. Dithering or otherwise, most games from this period are just going to look "wrong" unless you take some sort of measure to recreate their original viewing conditions. Some games used dithering that was based on CRT limitations, some games had built in PS1 texture wobble correction, some games have filters based on how it looks on an old LCD, some games have effects that only work on a handheld without a backlight, some games have textures designed to only look right as a particular internal resolution.

There's no catch all or easy solution, but erring towards original hardware is your best starting point.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: At first it seemed better than the Sega arcade port, I really liked the level on the raft, the real sensations of adventure, alternative gameplay. Cool level with columns. The levels are 2 times longer, so the walkthrough longer, the checkpoint is only in the middle. The last stages are made according to the residual principle and copy the last GnG, you just climb a few stairs and at the end the boss of the first game. The bosses are made in a balanced way, there is no checkpoint in front of them, so they are easier, except for the last ones on the second run. There is a level in the gut of a ghoul, like in Earthworm Jim, quite original, you are twisted around the level, like in Super Castlevania 4, then you ride on a platform through gases, the most boring thing is that they do not show how you get there and how you get out.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
The weapons were spoiled here, there is no strike in 4 directions, this is the same degradation as after SuperCastlevania 4 and Bloodlines. It’s mostly bad weapon here, thr boomerang, the Death scythe from a castlvania, the torch, the axe with a strange spiral trajectory, there was so better in the prequel. In fact, only the starting spear, the classic knife, the imba crossbow and the saintball for the second run are usable. Saintball is also a terrible shit, although it is strong, you can only throw one, on the half of the screen, the farther, the weaker. In GnG it was much nicer, like magic from the end of the gothic. With it, it is almost impossible to pass the boss Satan from the first and second games. It's hard to even get to them, the red devils start to cause problems like in the first game.. The game just broke me, I made a savestate before the bosses. Even with it, I spent dozens of attempts, he needs 30 strokes, I'm fucked up. All bosses are easily taken out with a crossbow, especially magical ones, you just smear Satan on the first try, you spam with arrows without stopping. The game is broken if you are forced to walk half the game with the worst, but quest weapon.
The mainboss is similar to Loki from the prequel, but a little more complicated, you need to understand how to jump on one platform, after a few trays you can kill him. He even upset me after this Satan, I freaked out, skiped with a savestate, but immediately replayed it so that there was a sense of completeness.
In general, its good game, beautiful graphics, original levels, but the weapons of the second run and real meinbosses are very annoying. 8/10

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9660109
The remaster is fantastic and the most accessible legit way to play the game unless you have a GameCube copy or manage to get your hands on a copy of Trilogy. The visuals and controls are great, and the sounds, music, progression, map layout and overall content are 1:1 to the original, unlike the Dead Space remake. Essentially, if you play the remaster, you're getting the full experience, and a good representation of it at that.

If you're a purist and want something closer to the untouched experience, download PrimeHack for Dolphin and play the Trilogy through that. Also a great way to play all three games. But keep in mind that the Trilogy lacks some of the minor touches the original GCN edition had.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9660146
The new controls are certainly more intuitive, but the game was originally designed around the more involved aiming controls and stuff. So when you play the remaster with twin stick control, it's super fucking easy. Like I am on Normal and have not come even close to dying at any point. I think the remaster supports a control option that mimics the original though, but I haven't tested it. It also has the Wiimote aiming controls if you're into that. If you have a Switch-compatible GC controller, it can be used to control the game exactly as it was on the original hardware. Visually the remaster is exceptional, and runs at 60FPS somehow despite the Switch's dogshit hardware.

Ultimately, I would recommend the remaster without any caveats, unless your mission is specifically to play the original code of the game in its purest form. The remaster is a straight visual upgrade without sacrificing any of the original's art direction or atmosphere. Control options are varied enough to give you whatever you want. It's got extra accessibility options, and some bonus features like concept art and 3D model viewers that the original didn't have.

TL;DR The remaster is definitely worth the purchase

I'm replaying the trilogy version because of the remaster. I think this is my 3rd or 4th playthrough since the Trilogy version came out. Going for a 100% playthrough.
The "Hunt down twelve artifacts" quest is pointless and adds nothing to the game except forcing you to backtrack. A lot of the fun of backtracking in Super Metroid is that most of it is optional: you're not forced into it, but you can get tons of new items and the 100% completion bonus. Progression to Mother Brain is tied to defeating the 4 main bosses.

But the Prime artifact quest is just needless padding. The game would benefit if you just cut the whole thing out. There's so much going back and forth between empty rooms.
I like Prime 2 better, but I remember it being even worse in that game.

>>9659545
It means promo art blastoise would probably look weird doing any physical attacks, because the original design is so bulky and has such stubby arms that it'd be rather difficult to make anything work and look good. You can see if you watch this video. They made the arms longer so that punch animations or other hand motions would look more normal, and even then that they pretty much rely on attacks and movements that don't involve hands at all.
The classic promo art and renders are nice, and there's nothing wrong with them, but they are static images. The pokken people had to make the model as it was to get blastoise to work well in actual motion.

The robots in megaman classic do have self-awareness and emotions, but what separates them from Reploids is the fact that they cannot act upon what they perceive and feel unless programmed to. Wily has to modify them into acting erratically and dangerously.
As for Rock in MM7, it could be that years of experience saving people and making choices, as well as continuous upgrades from Dr. Light eventually resulted in Rock developing a primitive form of agency that ALMOST emerged when he was about to shoot Wily (regardless of localization text because it sure looked like he was about to blast the old man's face right off). Light noticed this and thus began working on X. Is it canon? No, but it makes sense. Even our current-year primitive AI experiments eventually develops its own ideas that skirt the limits of what it's allowed to do, it's not far fetched.

>>9642587
Arbok gets glare, which is at least interesting. Plenty of options for poison for blue, not missing out. Sandshrew however is the best ground type pokemon in gen 1. Unless you go for speed abuse dugtrio. Cubone is solid too, but you get sandshrew earlier and it's better, so the winner Blue

Gloom getting petal dance makes it one of the best grass types in gen 1, weepinbell gets razor leaf, it's trash. Winner Red

Primeape is 2nd best fighting type in the game, getting one early in the game can be nice, persian is also possibly the 2nd best normal type, and has crit abuse and a great movepool so Tie.

Arcanine has fat stats, Ninetales has a few interesting moves, both fire, not really missing out over the other here another Tie

Pinsir vs Scyther, well, neither provide a counter to psychic. If we allow wing attack from yellow into play Scyther is the clear winner, otherwise its mostly a tie, but Id still edge scyther the winner since gets swords dance and such. So Red

Electabuzz and magmar both do the same thing. Just electric vs fire. I can't really call a winner here, so another tie. You don't get them in the same place, which is also interesting. One is in an area part of the main story, the other is not, but no major flaw or advantage on either.

Ultimately, red wins. I'll point out, if you want a grass type and you pick charmander or squirtle and play blue, you're fucked on grass, because bellsprout really sucks, petal dance vileplume is way better. Basically, scyther and vileplume clinch it for red. It's actually pretty balanced how they split it.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
I think its interesting how all three starters have different playstyles that all manage to have different pros and cons so that none of them truly feel hard if you play different ways. even beyond the "Bulbasaur resists the first three gyms, Charmander is weak to the first 2(possibly 3 if you grind him to Charizard before Lt. surge)
Bulbasaur is great for defensive and stat changing/stalling play. Just the fact that he reissts a lot of common types and has a big spongey HP makes him perfect for the typical G1 grind method of "weak Pokemon first turn, then switch". also has a surprisingly high Special/attack, which means it can hold its own.Just solid for learning game mechanics.
Squirtle is a nice balanced middle ground between defense, special and attack, learns the biggest variety of moves and can cover most types buy itself.
Charmander feels the easiest to grind with because so much of what you encounter are bug types and Pokemon witha weak special stat ; while his attack/special aren't actually higher than the Bulbasaur line his move pool centers more around stronger attacks early on. Feels geared towards players who just want to use damaging moves.

You can beat the game largely with just one of any of them, sure, but I'd say Bulbasaur is the easiest to build a team around early on, Charmander is good for grinding through the early game if you just want to muscle through with attacks until you can take advantage of mid game Pokemon that become available, and Squirtle is best if you largely want to focus on one -three Pokemon. But you can easily use Charmander to solo the game, or Squirtle to build a team around.
Personally, when I want to not use a starter I usually go with Charmander to grind through with ember, get a nidoran as a support until I can lean more on him and get to Cerulean and have access to all the Pokemon around there.

You could say Blue should have a Squirtle, but from a Japanese perspective, he should be using a Bulbasaur.
But if Red used the Charmander and the rival used Bulbasaur, that wouldn't make sense either, because the rival always chooses whatever Pokémon has an advantage against Red's choice of starter.
It's actually a pretty fucked up image.

posts.com:
It's a sad reality that the games that get remade...
- are already so good they are perfectly playable as they were
- are so well known they won't benefit from the extra exposure the remake provides
- are so beloved any minor changes will piss fans off
- are so historically important people will want to play the classic version anyway

This thread is instead for those games where a remake could be a game changer that will never happen, those games you see have something special and are full of unique potential but for one reason or another are not as good as they deserved to be. Post and discuss them

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9642142
it's kind of like translating Japanese to English. Shit is like a one to many situation all of the time simply because Japanese doesn't have a lot of ways to skin a cat (especially when compared to the nightmare gobblrfuck that is English) and so you could probably take a script in Japanese, give it to 5 different translators, and get 5 different translations, depending on all manner of things. Likewise, from a single blurry texture you could get 5 different interpretations by artists.

It's the problem of having to define one answer to an open question. It's like when gunpei yokoi defended using a black and white screen on the game boy. He said that if you draw two circles on top of each other on a whiteboard and say "it's a snowman" then people will fill the gaps in their mind of what the snowman looks like. Ask one artist to draw a detailed snowman to be "the" snowman in this, and someone observing it will say that it's not what they had imagined.

This is why movie adaptations of books can often seem off vs .the originals, because you read them and have an idea of what the characters look and sound like, all for it to be torn up when you see the Hollywood version where one team of (hopefully) interested people decided what every character and element would look like and would sound like and forced it upon everyone else.
It's also why Bill Watterson fought tooth and nail against merchandise for Calvin and Hobbes; He never wanted to get to the point of making a movie or tv show and having to decide what Hobbes' voice sounded like. That was for the reader to decide as they enjoyed the comic for themselves.

tl;dr a remake can basically never change graphics in any way without potentially alienating someone because there are too many ways to take something vague and turn it into something specific and inevitably, someone will like their own interpretation of it better.

I just beat Chrono Cross a few days ago and easily that game. It's not even hard to think of what to change either.
-spread all of the exposition dumps from the ending and from chronopolis throughout the entire game. make the time devourer clearly the antagonist earlier, reveal the FATE computer/Lynx earlier.

>>9649915
>>9650028
>"why don't devs just make great games for my failed console???"
devs want big sales. no one wants to make a huge game for a platform that only 5% of the players own, and get only a fraction of sales you could have.
Sega CD launched in late 1992 in US for $300. That'd be over $600 in today's money, for just an add-on, not full console, that still had 2D graphics and hardly impressive FMVs that were literal AVGN material.
By comparison, same year, Genesis cost $99 (would be $200-something today). PS1 launched for $300, then quickly dropped the price to $200. that's literally a price of a full new console.
Needless to say, no one in their right mind would make games for an add-on (which already limits the player base), that costs 3x more than the console itself.
obviously, Japan could have helped. but Mega Drive wasn't very popular there, and not only that, it already had a huge competitor in PC-Engine, that had a CD-addon earlier and also made a pretty successful Turbo Duo.

>for just an add-on, not full console, that still had 2D graphics and hardly impressive FMVs that were literal AVGN material.
The more I think about the whole Sega CD thing, and knowing the Genesis's weaknesses, the more I suspect they should've gone for a ground-up redesign and ASIC-ification.
Blob together the Genesis audio hardware with the Ricoh chip and add the extra sound memory.
Blob together the VDP with that custom Sega CD graphics chip, add the extra video RAM needed for full palette, 128K mode, extra effects etc.
Do a proper redesign of the audio/video filtering and amp logic (many Genesis revisions looked and sounded like ass because the amp/filter stage was borked).
Upclock the CPU to 12.5 MHz (same speed as the IRL Sega CD CPU).
Use a proper CD-ROM-grade drive.
Keep the cartridge slot for backcompat, have the console run in legacy mode when game logic is detected (it was doable, some of the later NEC consoles had the capability).
Ditch the internal save memory and make the save cartridge widely available.
Do a global Western launch early 1993 for $299.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>9654241
IMO "mid-generation" consoles have always been a bad idea. they never sell all that much. today they became a bit more normal, since every console is basically a PC that can get upgraded, so it can play all the same games but with better graphics.
but before that, what happened? you get a console that needs its own dedicated software that won't work on the "base" console. a company that made it needs to spread talent/effort between Genesis and Sega CD. more than that, it needs to advertise the new platform, and make some really good games for it to help the launch (like Mario / Zelda / Sonic tier). and the console STILL naturally won't sell that much, as parents don't want to shell out several hundred $ every 2 years. the players will feel betrayed their old console gets less support. 3rd party devs will hardly want to develop for it, learning all the nuance of a new platform to get a fraction of sales. most notably, you hardly reach any new consumers. and 2-3 years later it still gets BTFO'd by new generation of "proper" consoles that get advertized to high heavens and bring in the actual next gen hardware. ESPECIALLY so when we talk 2D —> 3D transition.
it's just a vicious cycle. you deliberately spread effort between many consoles, instead of focusing on one.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9660106
>There's not a single FF game that even attempt to recreate Amano's designs faithfully
That's not accurate. Obviously his designs needed to be modified for the 8-bit and 16-bit graphics, especially with the character sprites. But they're still drawing from his art. And his art appears more directly in the games as portraits and monster art.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9660106
Not sure if you're grasping all the purposes concept art can encompass. Yes it can be a literal translation, but more than often it is just inspiration at best for when the time comes to actually produce a product. One would be braindead to expect concept art to 100% represent a retro game. But I get what you are getting at. It does make for good marketing material. There is a stark contrast between his art and the game. But if you actually look, you can put the pieces together and realize what is represented in the work. Hence, the concept art is doing its job.
How many pieces of concept art for cars have you seen that actually near completely represent the official model that gets released? It's all about interpretation.

>>9654687
I agree with you. I’m always confused when people act like 3&K is the best of the genesis games. Its not a terrible game but I prefer 1, 2 or CD. Sonic 1 and 2 are great for reasons you mentioned. Linear, fast and fun almost arcade style games. Race through the level and beat the boss quickly, stopping only to get the chaos emeralds. Multiple paths but the best is always fast and gives lots of rings. Metropolis Zone in Sonic 2 feels like a preview of Sonic 3. Its long and gets old. The added content in 3 seems to just slow everything down. It felt like it was competing with something slower and more methodical like DKC of Yoshi Island rather than trying to be fast, arcadey sonic. All the different powerups and different kinds of bonus zones complicated things in the wrong way.

Of course levels like labyrinth Zone and Marble Garden Zone in Sonic 1 slow things down too. I love these levels. The difference is they are simpler in design and not as long and just don’t feel as padded out. Most levels in Sonic 3 wear out their welcome by the first zone in my opinion. Those slower levels in Sonic 1 remind me of 80’s platforming games. Alex Kidd, SMB, etc. The long ones in 3&K feel like Metropolis Zone times 3

Sonic CD is more about exploration and collection so the levels are more open. You can breeze through levels like in previous sonic games or you can try to find the collectables. Its a different game and I would say its a great twist. Rather tham just being longer and having more cinematic showpieces like 3, theres a real purpose and you’re actively looking for something.

I don’t mean to be too hard on 3&K. Saving makes up for my complaints and moves it from an arcade platformer and turns it into a longer experience like DKC, Super Metroid or Castlevanias. Instead of playing the whole game, the player is meant to play a level or two per sitting, keeping things fresh. It was an ok attempt at evolving Sonic and certainly better than 3d blast

Continuing my thoguht here:

Another defense of Sonic 3&K is that I really don’t know where else the series could have gone at that point. They couldn’t just keep making Sonic 2 level hacks forever. Sure Sonic Mania was great but should a new one have been released every year? Sonic CD was great too as a one-off experimental title, but it wasn’t the direction I would have taken the series. They went in one of the only directions they could have gone in by making longer levels, saving and more powerups and collectables. What else was there to do?

Maybe they could have eliminated levels and made it all one continuous (but still relatively linear) world like Castlevania 3. Branching level paths an so on.

Shortening down the levels to be like some of the real small ones in SMB3 wouldn’t have worked for Sonic. They added some gimmicks for 3 but making Sonic a new gimmick every level platformer like the excellent DKC2 would have desfroyed Sonic as well. Its just not Sonic. So given that I’m not sure where else they could have taken things, Sonic 3&K was a viable option.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: After the Atari crash Nintendo responded by heavily focusing on quality control, both as a way to improve the public reception of their games and as a way to gatekeep smaller developers and publishers from chipping away at their market share by releasing cheaper, lower-quality carts and games on Nintendo systems. It just sorta stuck around for a few console generations well after it stopped meaning anything.

>>9660863
It was the Original Nintendo Seal of Quality, Anon

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9660863

Pretty clever way to after the crash keep other developers at bay and at the same time signal quailty to reassure the customer.
Clever because OFFICIALLY they always just stated that the seal just meant PHYSICAL/hardware compability, your game will work with the console and not crash after a while, it also has been thouroughly tested for bugs etc - but they of course knew and that was what they HOPED that the seal gets associated with Nintendo making quality games, as in good and fun. A self-controlled medal under their own control.
That said it was not pure show, getting the seal was mandatory when publishing on their consoles and formally the seal was the reason for that long and hard certification process in terms of game testing and Nintendo's long list of content terms. So it really certified compability.
